com.saliman.entitypruner
Interface PruningState

public interface PruningState

This interface defines the valid pruning states for an entity. They are implemented as strings instead of an enum because we want it to be simple for clients to understand as the value gets passed back and forth.

Clients should be careful not to change the value of the entity's pruning state, and new values should be set to PRUNED_COMPLETE.

Server code should not allow updates to an entity in an UNPRUNED_PARTIAL state because it would result in a lot of fields being set incorrectly to null in the database.

Author:
Steven C. Saliman
See Also:
for more details about pruning entities.

Field Summary
static java.lang.String PRUNED_COMPLETE
          Constant representing a pruned entity that contains all its attributes.

          Constant representing a pruned entity that has had some of its attributes stripped out.
static java.lang.String UNPRUNED_COMPLETE

Field Detail

PRUNED_COMPLETE

static final java.lang.String PRUNED_COMPLETE
Constant representing a pruned entity that contains all its attributes. A COMPLETE_PRUNED entity can be unpruned and safely saved to a database.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

UNPRUNED_COMPLETE

static final java.lang.String UNPRUNED_COMPLETE
Constant representing an unpruned entity thas all its attributes. This is the state of an entity when it comes from the database.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

PRUNED_PARTIAL

static final java.lang.String PRUNED_PARTIAL
Constant representing a pruned entity that has had some of its attributes stripped out. A PRUNED_PARTIAL entity is useful when clients only need a small subset of information about an entity.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

UNPRUNED_PARTIAL

static final java.lang.String UNPRUNED_PARTIAL
Constant representing an entity that has been unpruned, but does not have all its attributes. Applications probably don't want to allow an UNPRUNED_PARTIAL entity to be saved to the database because we have no way to tell the difference between an attribute that was never sent to the client, and one where the attribute was intentionally set to null. Pruning an entity with a "select" argument will cause an entity to be set to this state.

See Also:
Constant Field Values
